poem:
**Live 11:56**

In Munich, the clocks click like microphones,  
and men arrive wrapped in weather.  

A drone factory hums—  
a new kind of beehive—  
while Zelenskyy is shown the future  
in steel and bright rotors.  

Down the street, a chant rises:  
no shah, no mullah.  

Inside, Europe practices its next sentence  
under perfect spring light.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Friedrich Merz arrives at Munich Security Conference ahead of speech – live 11.56am GMT Focus on Ukraine with Zelenskyy, foreign minister Sybiha attending side events As mentioned earlier, there are lots of activities on the sidelines of the main conference that allow for more public and private diplomacy (10:53). Earlier today, German and Ukrainian foreign ministers opened “Ukraine House,” a special space for additional events on Ukraine’s future. And German defence minister Boris Pistorius is now showing the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, around a drone factory near Munich. Zelenskyy will deliver his conference speech tomorrow late morning, speaking after Rubio, von der Leyen and Starmer, among others. 11.28am GMT German chancellor Merz arrives ahead of his Munich speech German chancellor Friedrich Merz has now arrived in Munich, presenting his 2026 spring look (the weather is much nicer today, compared to yesterday’s torrential rain). He is due on the main stage in just over an hour. 11.13am GMT What does Europe’s future look like? - Q&A with Jon Henley Separately, our Europe correspondent Jon Henley is now answering your questions on Europe’s future on our reader Q&A below. Feel free to join the chat with Jon as he offers his insight on what lies ahead for Europe. Related: Reader Q&A: what does Europe’s future look like? Post your questions for Jon Henley 11.11am GMT 'No shah, no mullah' Iran protest outside Munich conference in Munich Ahead of the conference getting under way, there is a demonstration not too far from the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
